ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about the art of autobiography and meaning making of your own story, as well as about African American perspectives across time.
How to better close read nonfiction prose and poetry
skills of close reading and realtime discussion; critical thinking and writing

I engaged in detail with black narratives in a way that I haven't before. It was unlike any other english class that I've taken thus far in that we didn't just read and analyze, we deconstructed, with great great respect not only for the author and the text, but also for the lived experiences of the individuals in the classroom. I improved my analytical skills, was lucky enough to be exposed to a few books by authors I wouldn't have read as deeply, and grew a lot as a reader and as a learner.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Great instructor, interesting material, meaningful assignments.
Weaknesses: None, really. Just know it goes fast in summer session!

This course was very well structured I felt like the texts really build upon one another. The only "weakness" of the course was that the pacing was really fast, but I think that's just the nature of YSS.
this course embraces a wide variety of topics in (especially) contemporary (African) American culture and engages with inspiring texts of alternative perspectives

I don't see very many weaknesses with this course. I think that generally the summer format is kind of terrible (breakneck pace and really really draining) but the professor did their best to mitigate the stress and to allow room to breathe and to grow and learn within it all. The course itself had no weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This course is wonderful if you are interested in African-American voices and history within the United States.
Overall yes, though it depends on their previous familiarity with norms of literary criticism and number of works

100%. It's amazing, and black narratives, esp afam narratives, are crucial to understanding the fabric of this country. It also pushes one's ability to read comprehend and analyze quickly, an important skill in today's world

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.

extras.title: AFAM S305 01/ENGL S305 01 - African American Autobiography
